title: If you didn't plan to bring back Solo Queue you should have said it months ago
body:
I'm not even that mad about Solo Queue being scrapped. I have faith in Riot that they'll eventually get DQ close to balanced. What I'm mad about is how they've played us for months. It pisses me off that you guys constantly say "We're working on it" which essentially means "It's never coming". If you want to shit on our plate at least do it with a straight when you make the decision.

Edit: Most of you seem to be forgetting this post where they had everything planned out. 

http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/miscellaneous/HGblb9fH-the-2016-ranked-season-updates-on-dynamic-ranked-and-your-feedback

Funny how it went from 

> We need to work out a few implementation details

to

> we've made the decision to not bring back solo queue.

____________________________________________
Here are some things Rioters have said about Solo Queue 

Riot ScuttleChris said this 2 months ago

> I believe this is where the disconnect is.

> **We aren't pro or anti soloqueue.** Anything is on the table to fix the current state of the queues, including bringing back soloqueue.

> We are anti long queue times at diamond and above, we are anti unfair match making which seems to be happening when full premades run into solo players again at diamond and above.

> We are pro team play, and pro being able to play with your friends (whether you have one friend, two, or three).

> I don't want to see us be dogmatic about dynamic queue either - **I'm in favor of any solution that helps all these things happen.**

RiotTuxedo said this a year ago on what he though about what ranked meant

> Ranked, in my humble opinion, is more about a long term measurement of your own personal growth and knowledge about the game. When you stop thinking about winning individual games and rather improving your gameplay for the long term you'll realize it's in your best interest to focus on yourself individually and what you can do better rather than what your teammates are doing wrong.

> Time and time again I've heard pro players say you can't control what teammates you get matched with or how well they play, the only thing you can control is how well you play personally. Becoming a high ranked player is about getting better individually to a point where you consistent play well.

The problem is that there are fundamental pain points Riot won't be able to fix with all the fudge factors in the world.

DQ gives players the same MMR when they're queued with their usual premade as when they decide to play a game solo - spoiler alert, the MMR is going to be wrong in one of those cases.

> [{quoted}](name=Mandang0,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=wV9tAKA7,comment-id=0005,timestamp=2016-05-31T23:17:07.754+0000)

> DQ gives players the same MMR when they're queued with their usual premade as when they decide to play a game solo - spoiler alert, the MMR is going to be wrong in one of those cases.

This is wrong.  The effective MMR of a premade is not just the average of the MMRs of the members.

The MMR might be wrong anyway, but it's not because Riot isn't taking premade-ness into account, but because that particular team is at a different point on the individual skill vs. team coordination spectrum compared to the average team.

Being skilled at League means more than one thing, or to put it another way, there's more than one skill that affects your chance of winning a game.  Individual mechanics are part of it, but coordinating with people you know well and coordinating with people you are playing with for the first time are both skills too (different from each other).

The real pain point that is affecting players like Scarra is the high cost of giving people role selection.  If you can't just throw 10 people of similar MMR into two buckets and let them fight it out over who gets what role, then it becomes much harder to make matches at all, let alone quality ones, especially when you have few players of similar skill level to choose from in the first place.

But I don't think they *should* go back to just throwing 10 players into 2 buckets -- for all the costs of the system that got us away from fighting over roles, *it got us away from fighting over roles* and that is a huge accomplishment that overshadows all of the problems with the current system, in my opinion.

> [{quoted}](name=Partholonian,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=wV9tAKA7,comment-id=00050000,timestamp=2016-06-01T03:27:23.032+0000)

> But I don't think they *should* go back to just throwing 10 players into 2 buckets -- for all the costs of the system that got us away from fighting over roles, *it got us away from fighting over roles* and that is a huge accomplishment that overshadows all of the problems with the current system, in my opinion.

This is entirely independent from dynamic queue.  In fact, forcing dynamic queue alongside role selection is only straining the matchmaker harder.  If Riot returned to solo/duo (with role preferences) it'd be easier to provide both short queue times and desired roles.

And I couldn't care less for the discussion of what a rank does or doesn't mean - all I care about is the quality of matches, which will suffer on a player-by-player basis in the interest of letting different-sized premades play.

Absolutely correct. Its the addition of too many complicated and poorly designed systems that causes so much consternation. We already had poor systems in place with the League System and ELO system coexisting to provide the same function, adding additional poorly designed systems on top of will only make an already complicated mess more complicated and messy.

What really needs to happen is this:

1. The return of ranked solo queue. Only solo players allowed. It has its own MMR that pertains to this game mode.

2. The return of team ranked 5s queue. Only full 5 teams are allowed. It has its own MMR that pertains to this game mode.

3. Change Dynamic queue to duo/trio queue that only allows duos and trios. It has its own MMR that pertains to this game mode.

4. Never allow 4 man premades to participate in ranked play. This is the most toxic environment with solo players suffering greatly. Eliminate this possibility entirely.

5. Selecting ranked play with any number of viable partners automatically puts the team into the correct queue given the number of players in the lobby.

6. Rank displays should show solo skill level, duo/trio skill level, and team 5s skill level, as well as a composite skill level that incorporates all data from all ranked matches regardless of queue type played in. All 4 of these rankings should be displayed for the players. Separate end of season rewards should apply for various accomplishments within each of these settings with the greatest rewards for a high Composite Ranking.

> But I don't think they *should* go back to just throwing 10 players into 2 buckets -- for all the costs of the system that got us away from fighting over roles, *it got us away from fighting over roles* and that is a huge accomplishment that overshadows all of the problems with the current system, in my opinion.

It also took away the element of team cooperation and communication in lobby to put each player in an ideal and optimal scenario, something high level players like myself always did in every lobby. Op.gg the whole team, see who is best on what champs, figure out who is best where, then suggest a team composition that puts everyone in the best chance for success. You see this a lot from diamond+ players because its the most effective way to ensure maximum chance for success and a win. As you alluded to earlier, part of the problem with high level play is that Riot REMOVED this element of team coordination and cooperation from the lobby, discouraging teamwork in the process, and this hurts high elo players far more dramatically than low elo players. Most high elo players are willing to do what is required to give them the best chance to win, low level players with poor, selfish, attitudes never did this before and still aren't doing this now. It is a primary reason why they remain lower level players, its a team game and they refuse to act like a proper teammate.

So sure, it eliminated fighting over roles, but it also eliminated teamwork in the lobby, a key factor in succeeding and earning a W. This is obviously a net loss in a team game as the detrimental factor of eliminating the possibility of cooperative teamwork before the game even starts weighs heavier on the quality of game spectrum than players not cooperating out of selfishness or spite. Those types of players were never going to cooperate in the first place, were always going to degrade the quality of the games, and still do with the current system as it functions but now they are more difficult to identify and dodge. This has a negative impact on quality players with good team skills and completely invalidates what is usually the best skill they have: organizing an effective strategy with the team. Ultimately, we traded not fighting for roles (something high level players didn't usually do any ways) for lower quality games and pairings (something that effects high level players far more than low level players). In the end its a net loss and not much of an accomplishment since it contributes further flaws to an already severely flawed ranking system. That's never a good thing.
